natural problem:
The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$
natural solution: &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda> n. x powr n) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos(2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin(2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "sorted_list_of_set {alpha k | k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34} = [alpha k . k \<leftarrow> [1..34]]"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> P (z k) = 0"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda> n. x powr n) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos(2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin(2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "sorted_list_of_set {alpha k | k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34} = [alpha k . k \<leftarrow> [1..34]]"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> P (z k) = 0"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a complex polynomial $P(x)$ defined by $P(x) = \left( \sum_{n=0}^{17} x^n \right)^2 - x^{17}$, and a sequence of complex numbers $z_k$ defined by $z_k = r_k (\cos(2 \pi \alpha_k) + i \sin(2 \pi \alpha_k))$ for $1 \leq k \leq 34$, where the $\alpha_k$ are real numbers sorted in ascending order. If $P(z_k) = 0$ for all $k$ in this range, find the sum of the first five $\alpha_k$ values. The final answer is $159 / 323$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes z_k r_k alpha_k :: complex and P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>k. x powr k) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> P (z_k) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> z_k = r_k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha_k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha_k))"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> 0 < alpha_k \<and> alpha_k \<le> 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 33 \<longrightarrow> alpha_k \<le> alpha_{k+1}"
and h5 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> r_k > 0"
shows  "alpha_1 + alpha_2 + alpha_3 + alpha_4 + alpha_5 = 159 / 323"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes z_k r_k alpha_k :: complex and P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>k. x powr k) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> P (z_k) = 0"

and h5 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> r_k > 0"
shows  "alpha_1 + alpha_2 + alpha_3 + alpha_4 + alpha_5 = 159 / 323"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Given a function $P(z) = (z^0 + z^1 + ... + z^{17})^2 - z^{17}$, and a sequence of complex numbers $z_k = r_k * (cos(2\pi\alpha_k) + i*sin(2\pi\alpha_k))$ for $1 \leq k \leq 34$ where $r_k > 0$ and $0 < \alpha_k \leq 1$. 

It is also given that $\alpha_k$ is a non-decreasing sequence and that $P(z_k) = 0$ for each $k$. 

Find the sum $\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 + \alpha_3 + \alpha_4 + \alpha_5$. The final answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.

(* ### Problem

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x z_k :: complex and α_k r_k :: real and P :: "complex => complex"
assumes h0 : "1 * x powr 0 + 1 * x powr 1 + 1 * x powr 2 + ... + 1 * x powr 17 = P x"
and h1 : "P x powr 2 - x powr 17 = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. z_k = r_k * (cos (2 * pi * α_k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * α_k))"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 0 < α_k \<and> α_k \<le> α_(k+1) \<and> α_k < 1 \<and> r_k > 0"
and h4 : "card {k. z_k = 0} = 34"
shows  "α_1 + α_2 + α_3 + α_4 + α_5 = 159 / 323"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]

theorem
fixes x z_k :: complex and α_k r_k :: real and P :: "complex => complex"
assumes h0 : "1 * x powr 0 + 1 * x powr 1 + 1 * x powr 2 + ... + 1 * x powr 17 = P x"
and h1 : "P x powr 2 - x powr 17 = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. z_k = r_k * (cos (2 * pi * α_k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * α_k))"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 0 < α_k \<and> α_k \<le> α_(k+1) \<and> α_k < 1 \<and> r_k > 0"
and h4 : "card {k. z_k = 0} = 34"
shows  "α_1 + α_2 + α_3 + α_4 + α_5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Given the series $x^0 + x^1 + x^2 + \ldots + x^{17} = P(x)$, where $P(x)$ satisfies the equation $P(x)^2 - x^{17} = 0$. 

Further, each $z_k$ is defined as $z_k = r_k \times (cos(2\pi\alpha_k) + i \times sin(2\pi\alpha_k))$, where each $\alpha_k$ is a real number between 0 and 1 (0 < $\alpha_k$ < 1), each $r_k$ is a positive real number, and the sequence $\{\alpha_k\}$ is non-decreasing ($\alpha_k$ ≤ $\alpha_{k+1}$).

If there are exactly 34 values of $k$ for which $z_k = 0$, find the sum of the first five $\alpha_k$'s. The final answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>n. x ^ n) {0..17})^2 - x^17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> r k > 0"
and h3 : "0 < alpha 1 \<and> (\<forall> k. 2 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> alpha (k - 1) \<le> alpha k) \<and> alpha 34 < 1"
and h4 : "card {k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<and> P (z k) = 0} = 34"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>n. x ^ n) {0..17})^2 - x^17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> r k > 0"
and h3 : "0 < alpha 1 \<and> (\<forall> k. 2 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> alpha (k - 1) \<le> alpha k) \<and> alpha 34 < 1"
and h4 : "card {k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<and> P (z k) = 0} = 34"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A complex function P is defined by $P(x) = (sum_{n=0}^{17} x^n)^2 - x^{17}$. Another sequence of complex numbers $z_k$ is defined for $1 \leq k \leq 34$ by $z_k = r_k*(cos(2\pi\alpha_k) + i*sin(2\pi\alpha_k))$ where $r_k$ is a sequence of positive real numbers and $\alpha_k$ is a sequence of real numbers such that $0 < \alpha_1 \leq \alpha_2 \leq \alpha_3 \leq ... \leq \alpha_{34} < 1$. If the function P has 34 roots, and all of these roots are among the values $z_k$, find the sum of the first five terms of the sequence $\alpha_k$, i.e., $\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 + \alpha_3 + \alpha_4 + \alpha_5$. The final answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = ((1 + x + x powr 2 + ... + x powr 17) powr 2) - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"

shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex"
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = ((1 + x + x powr 2 + ... + x powr 17) powr 2) - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> 0 < alpha k \<and> alpha k < 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> r k > 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34 \<longrightarrow> P (z k) = 0"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Given a complex function $P(x)$ defined as $P(x) = (1 + x + x^2 + ... + x^{17})^2 - x^{17}$, a sequence of complex numbers $z_k$, and real sequences $r_k$ and $\alpha_k$ such that $z_k = r_k * (cos(2\pi\alpha_k) + i*sin(2\pi\alpha_k))$ for all natural numbers $k$. 

Assume that for each $k$ between 1 and 34 (inclusive), the sequence $\alpha_k$ lies strictly between 0 and 1, and the sequence $r_k$ is strictly positive. Additionally, $P(z_k) = 0$ for all such $k$.

Find the sum of the first five terms of the sequence $\alpha_k$. The final answer is $159/323$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem 
  fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>k. x^k) {0..17})^2 - x^17"
and h1 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..34}. P (of_real (r k) * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..34}. r k > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..33}. alpha k \<le> alpha (k + 1)"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem 
  fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>k. x^k) {0..17})^2 - x^17"
and h1 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..34}. P (of_real (r k) * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..34}. r k > 0"
and h3 : "\<forall>k \<in> {1..33}. alpha k \<le> alpha (k + 1)"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given a function $P(x)$ defined as $P(x) = (x^0 + x^1 + x^2 + ... + x^{17})^2 - x^{17}$, and a sequence of real numbers $r(k)$ and $\alpha(k)$ for $k$ in the set $\{1, 2, ..., 34\}$, where $r(k) > 0$ for all $k$ and $\alpha(k)$ is non-decreasing ($\alpha(k) \le \alpha(k+1)$ for $k$ in $\{1, 2, ..., 33\}$). 

Also given is that $P$ evaluated at $r(k) * (cos(2\pi*\alpha(k)) + i*sin(2\pi*\alpha(k)))$ is zero for all $k$ in $\{1, 2, ..., 34\}$.

Find the sum of the first five terms of the $\alpha$ sequence. The final answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = ((1 + x + x powr 2 + ... + x powr 17) powr 2) - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34) \<longrightarrow> P (z k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34) \<longrightarrow> (0 < alpha k \<and> alpha k < 1) \<and> r k > 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k < 34) \<longrightarrow> alpha k \<le> alpha (k + 1)"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and alpha :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = ((1 + x + x powr 2 + ... + x powr 17) powr 2) - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * alpha k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * alpha k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34) \<longrightarrow> P (z k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 34) \<longrightarrow> (0 < alpha k \<and> alpha k < 1) \<and> r k > 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. (1 \<le> k \<and> k < 34) \<longrightarrow> alpha k \<le> alpha (k + 1)"
shows  "alpha 1 + alpha 2 + alpha 3 + alpha 4 + alpha 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a complex function $P(x) = (1 + x + x^2 + ... + x^{17})^2 - x^{17}$ and a sequence of complex numbers $z_k = r_k * (cos(2\pi\alpha_k) + i*sin(2\pi\alpha_k))$ where $r_k$ is a positive real number and $\alpha_k$ is a real number between 0 and 1. The sequence $z_k$ satisfies the property that $P(z_k) = 0$ for $k$ ranging from 1 to 34. Moreover, the $\alpha_k$ are ordered, i.e., $\alpha_k \leq \alpha_{k+1}$ for $k$ ranging from 1 to 33. Find the sum of the first five $\alpha_k$, i.e., $\alpha_1 + \alpha_2 + \alpha_3 + \alpha_4 + \alpha_5$. The final answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and α :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>n. x powr n) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * α k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * α k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 0 < α k \<and> α k \<le> α (k + 1) \<and> α 34 < 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. r k > 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. P (z k) = 0"
shows  "α 1 + α 2 + α 3 + α 4 + α 5 = 159 / 323"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial $$P(x)=(1+x+x^2+\ldots+x^{17})^2-x^{17}$$has 34 complex zeros of the form $z_k=r_k\left[\cos(2\pi\alpha_k)
+i\sin(2\pi\alpha_k)\right]$, $k=1,2,3,\ldots,34$, with $0<\alpha_1\le\alpha_2\le\alpha_3\le\dots\le\alpha_{34}<1$ and $r_k>0$. Find $\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5.$ The final Answer is \frac{159}{323}
 ### Proof
 Note that for $x\ne1$, \begin{align} P(x)&=\left(\frac{x^{18}-1}{x-1}\right)^2-x^{17} \end{align}so \begin{align} \cr (x-1)^2P(x)&=(x^{18}-1)^2-x^{17}(x-1)^2\cr &=x^{36}-2x^{18}+1-x^{19}+2x^{18}-x^{17}\cr
 &=x^{36}-x^{19}-x^{17}+1\cr &=x^{19}(x^{17}-1)-(x^{17}-1)\cr &=(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1). \end{align}Then \[P(x)=\frac{(x^{19}-1)(x^{17}-1)}{(x-1)^2}.\]Thus the zeros of $P(x)$ are the 34 complex numbers other than 1 which satisfy $x^{17}=1$ or $x^{19}=1$.
 It follows that $\alpha_1= \frac{1}{19},$ $\alpha_2= \frac{1}{17},$ $\alpha_3= \frac{2}{19},$ $\alpha_4= \frac{2}{17},$ and $\alpha_5= \frac{3}{19},$ so \[\alpha_1+\alpha_2+\alpha_3+\alpha_4+\alpha_5= \boxed{\frac{159}{323}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and r :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and α :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (sum (\<lambda>n. x powr n) {0..17}) powr 2 - x powr 17"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. z k = r k * (cos (2 * pi * α k) + \<i> * sin (2 * pi * α k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 0 < α k \<and> α k \<le> α (k + 1) \<and> α 34 < 1"
and h3 : "\<forall> k. r k > 0"
and h4 : "\<forall> k. P (z k) = 0"
shows  "α 1 + α 2 + α 3 + α 4 + α 5 = 159 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
We have a complex function $P(x) = (x^0 + x^1 + x^2 + ... + x^{17})^2 - x^{17}$. 

Also, we have a sequence of complex numbers $z(k)$, where each $z(k)$ is given by $r(k) * (\cos(2\pi \alpha(k)) + i\sin(2\pi\alpha(k)))$. 

Each $\alpha(k)$ is a real number that is greater than $0$, less than or equal to $\alpha(k+1)$, and $\alpha(34)$ is less than $1$. 

Each $r(k)$ is a real number greater than $0$. 

It is given that $P(z(k)) = 0$ for all $k$. 

Find the sum of the first five terms of the sequence $\alpha(k)$, i.e., $\alpha(1) + \alpha(2) + \alpha(3) + \alpha(4) + \alpha(5)$. The final Answer is $\frac{159}{323}$.
